articles.headline: Trump Attacks Whistle-Blower’s Sources and Alludes to Punishment for Spies
articles.snippet: “You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart with spies and treason, right?” the president asked a room full of American diplomats.
articles.abstract: “You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart with spies and treason, right?” the president asked a room full of American diplomats.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump told staff members at the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday that he wants to know who provided information to a whistle-blower about his phone call with the president of Ukraine, saying that whoever did so was “close to a spy” and that “in the old days” spies were dealt with differently.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Security Tightens Over Protests in Egypt
articles.snippet: Several small anti-government protests broke out in Egypt, despite a pre-emptive crackdown in which nearly 2,000 Egyptians were arrested.
articles.abstract: Several small anti-government protests broke out in Egypt, despite a pre-emptive crackdown in which nearly 2,000 Egyptians were arrested.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read more about Friday’s protests in Egypt.]
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan

articles.headline: Brace Yourself for the Internet Impeachment
articles.snippet: Disinformation experts are preparing for fast-twitch media manipulation, droves of false and misleading claims and hyper-polarized audiences fiercely clinging to their side’s version of reality.
articles.abstract: Disinformation experts are preparing for fast-twitch media manipulation, droves of false and misleading claims and hyper-polarized audiences fiercely clinging to their side’s version of reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the impeachment inquiry against President Trump was announced on Tuesday, the president’s re-election campaign blasted an email to supporters, urging them to defend Mr. Trump against the “baseless and disgusting attacks.” Facebook quickly filled with ads for impeachment-themed merchandise, including $3 “Impeach Now!” bumper stickers and $35 “Impeach This!” T-shirts. In a private chat room, pro-Trump internet trolls discussed which memes, videos and news stories to push on social media in order to reclaim the narrative.

articles.headline: SoftBank Bet Big on Disruptive Companies. Many Have Not Paid Off.
articles.snippet: The Japanese technology company’s investments in WeWork, Uber, Sprint and other businesses have produced disappointing results, raising questions about how it picks companies.
articles.abstract: The Japanese technology company’s investments in WeWork, Uber, Sprint and other businesses have produced disappointing results, raising questions about how it picks companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has taken an Uber, sent a Slack message or enjoyed a free beer at a WeWork owes a little something to Masayoshi Son.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Wall Street Deflates America’s Favorite Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Companies like WeWork and Uber were expected to become a new generation of corporate giants. But investors have backed away.
articles.abstract: Companies like WeWork and Uber were expected to become a new generation of corporate giants. But investors have backed away.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the year when America’s biggest start-ups would finally make their triumphant debut on the stock market.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Stephen Grocer and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: In Trump’s Ukraine Phone Call, Alarmed Aides Saw Trouble
articles.snippet: The alarm among officials who heard the exchange between President Trump and his Ukrainian counterpart led to an extraordinary effort to keep many more people from learning about it.
articles.abstract: The alarm among officials who heard the exchange between President Trump and his Ukrainian counterpart led to an extraordinary effort to keep many more people from learning about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No one bothered to put special limits on the number of people allowed to sit in the “listening room” in the White House to monitor the phone call because it was expected to be routine. By the time the call was over 30 minutes later, it quickly became clear that it was anything but.

articles.headline: The White-Collar Job Apocalypse That Didn’t Happen
articles.snippet: Economists once warned that office jobs in the United States would soon follow factory jobs in moving overseas. New research suggests that jobs may be moving to other parts of the country instead.
articles.abstract: Economists once warned that office jobs in the United States would soon follow factory jobs in moving overseas. New research suggests that jobs may be moving to other parts of the country instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ron Kincaid remembers what it was like to worry that his job would be sent overseas.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Has a New Chief Executive. His Job Won’t Be Easy.
articles.snippet: Charles Scharf, a longtime banker and the current chief executive at BNY Mellon, will take over the scandal-plagued bank.
articles.abstract: Charles Scharf, a longtime banker and the current chief executive at BNY Mellon, will take over the scandal-plagued bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has finally found someone willing to take the hardest job in banking.
